abstract: Shooting of James Goggles and Stallone Trosper, members of Northern Arapaho Tribe, by caucasian man Roy Clyde at alcohol detox facility in Riverton, Wyo, has heightened tensions between American Indian and white communities; tribal officials are calling for federal investigation into whether shooting, which killed Trosper and critically wounded Goggles, was a bias attack; tensions date back to Riverton's founding in 1905, when city was carved out of Wind River Reservation for white settlement.
lead_paragraph: On a recent afternoon, a white man, who said he was sick of the homeless people who linger in parks, walked into an alcohol detox facility and shot two Native Americans, killing one.

headline.main: In Wyoming, Shooting Highlights Divide Between a City and a Reservation
headline.print_headline: In Wyoming, Two Communities Struggling to Find Common Ground

snippet: On a recent afternoon, a white man, who said he was sick of the homeless people who linger in parks, walked into an alcohol detox facility and shot two Native Americans, killing one.
